Many years ago (about 10) I designed and built this CNC mill.
I was asked to share it (I have seen in the movie of my ThingMaker Extruder).
Even my 3D printer was built partly with my cutter.
We as the public at that time I had done. The designs are in CorelDraw
I hope it will be helpful for those who plan to build a CNC.

The machine is constructed using aluminum profiles standard, commonly available.
The drives and snails are all ball.
For the Z axis, I used a single trolley, if I remember correctly, by 120 mm.
All markings, holes and threads (6mm.), were made at home with just a drill press and chain guide.
The turning and milling I had made leaning to a workshop outside (I had the necessary equipment).
The bearings used on the screws (1 screw), are special, they work both tension and compression on the outside and have 3 holes at 120 degrees useful for fixing, no need to ring support, (these I remember they cost very much), but are essential to prevent games in the axes.
The Y-axis has two trucks side by side on each side.
The electronics, mosfet, I've designed and self-built drawing inspiration from various schemes found on the internet.
The fairings I had made in fiberglass.
The entire machine, excluding the plan of work, I had painted to prevent oxidation of the aluminum.
I did a lot of milling, the power tool Kress photos is passed away and was replaced.
The work area is about 400x400x110.
How to use control software from PC Mach3.
If you are really interested please contact me, I will try to answer them.
Hello hello.

title: Polygon Columns with Holes and a Twist (Customizable)

description.text:
This is a Customizer environment in which you can design an array of up to 10 columns to fit your vision. You specify the location and parameters for each column. Each column is an extrusion of a basic regular polygon (triangle, square, pentagon, etc.) Create your object by specifying the X, Y location for the center of each column, the Z height of the column above the base, the size of the column (i.e. the diameter of the smallest circle that can enclose the column), and the twist (if any) for the column. In addition, each column can have a hole with the hole size, polygon shape and depth specified. You can specify the dimensions of the rectangular base supporting the columns (or, use zero base thickness for no base).
Columns can overlap. Holes can be larger than a column. Holes can be very shallow, or they can go through the entire column and base. Columns can be twisted or plain. If you want fewer than 10 columns or holes, specify zero diameter for each unwanted column/hole. So, what might this make? I hope there are lots of possibilities. Pen holders? Nail polish holders? Stands for objects supported by a field of columns? Supports for motors, circuit boards, sensors, gears, art objects? . . . A wide range of useful (and useless) objects can be created. I began this because I wanted a variety of bases for circuit boards and some storage racks for little jars of paint. My goal was to create a Customizer Thing with a reasonable range of flexibility. Obviously, that flexibility means you have to design and fill in the details -- in this case the parameters for each column in your creation. See the Customizer input panel for notes on the parameters. (Scroll down in Customizer to see all of them; there are a lot of parameters.) -- Enjoy.
[If your design needs exactly 4 columns located at the corners of a rectangle, you might try the more restricted version I developed before adding the options (and complexity) of this Thing. See: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1375390 ]

The Polygon_Columns_With_Holes_and_a_Twist.scad file contains the object descriptions and the initial parameter values. Customizer is a convenient way to change the parameter values to meet your needs. Or, you can use OpenSCAD for more extensive modifications.
The Desk_Set_Example.stl file is the object created by the default values when you open the .scad file in Customizer. It shows some of the options for columns. It uses 8 of the possible 10 columns and a variety of sizes, shapes, and twists. You are encouraged to change the parameters to create a design that meets your needs.

description.header: Project: Polygon Columns with Posts and a Twist
description.text:
Objectives: --Introduce 3-D design by providing an environment to create complex and interesting 3-D objects.
--Apply basic geometric concepts by utilizing a Cartesian coordinate system for describing and locating the components of the objects.
--Encourage development of the basic OpenSCAD to add or change the options available. Audiences: Middle school through adult. It could be used as part of introducing the basic concepts of Cartesian space. Or, it could be used to demonstrate how those concepts apply to the design of complex objects. Preparation: Very little background is needed to start using this Thing in projects. The Thingiverse Customizer will allow allow students to see a visualization of the objects they have developed. Or, the free OpenSCAD application can be installed on local computers. If 3-D printing is available, students can create the objects to get a better understanding of their designs.
For students who want to explore and modify the OpenSCAD file, I have added some basic comments to identify the sections. The file uses Customizer's data input feature, modules (subroutines) to actually generate the base, columns, and holes, by passing variable values, The logical concepts of union and difference create the final object. Steps Steps are the same as in any design/build project:
• Determine the goals for the object being designed
• Sketch out the object
• Assign dimensions to the columns
• Plot the locations of the columns
  • Enter the dimensions and locations in OpenSCAD or Customizer
    • • See what results in the Customizer 3-D view window..
    • Repeat the previous steps until you are ready to accept the resulting object. Results Depending on the learning objectives, the resulting objects can be evaluated by whether they demonstrate:
    • An understanding of geometric concepts (e.g. x, y, z coordinates; regular polygons, extruding 2-Figures into 3-D objects, twisting 3-D objects),
    • Accomplishing design goals, perhaps based on assigned options (e.g. design a holder for nail polish bottles, or a holder for small paint bottles, a 3-D column graph, multi-post stands for showcase display of objects, or ...)
    • Aesthetics of the object (e.g. balance, symmetry, etc.)
    • Understanding of the OpenSCAD programming concepts used (explaining how it works, or modifying it to slanted columns, creating a display stand with shaped post tops for a complex object (perhaps by creating an OpenSCAD description of object, floating it above the columns, and then subtracting the object) Test Printing Printing always seems to produce surprises. Two suggestions that have helped me: • If the column locations/sizes are critical, run a test print with a thin base and interrupt the printing as soon as the columns appear. There is no reason to wait for the whole object to print before learning those measurements need to be adjusted.
    • for student objects, scale them to a relatively small size when preparing them for printing. Make any adjustments at a small scale before printing them full scale.

description.text: Update: After some hard landings I realized it was not a great idea to have the landing gear integrated into the motor mount / arm. Also it was getting in the way of trying a new bottom mounted motor. So I redesigned the arm to be easier to use for a bottom mounted motor and made the landing gear a separate piece that can be replaced in the case of an accident, or when I ran into a wall. This is my version of MikeB's Crossfire. I was having a few problems printing the top plate and also opened it up a bit. I wanted to use a motor mount within the control arm and also strengthen up the actual gear and get as much length as possible. The only drawback is you have to print one at a time. Its large enough it has to be printed at an angle on your build platform (should be easy to shorten it and print multiples). For my bottom plate I am using: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124868 MikeyB's original was a great base so everything pretty much goes together as it does.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32281/#instructions

title: Gangsta Chess Set as one build plate

description.text:
I've taken Renosis' awesome Gangsta chess set and put all pieces on one build plate (hexagonal packing). There are 8 pawns, 2 bishops, 2 rooks, 2 knights, and a king. I've also added in 2 queens (the second one is for when your first pawn makes it to the other side!) and 3 extra gangstas, just for, you know, more awesome. There are two STLs... decide which you want to print:
the 1" feet file has 1" diameter feet on each piece
the 1.6" feet file is the original sized pieces and the larger ones are 1.6" diameter on their feet. Choose the appropriate size for your chess board, or scale it as desired. I've also included the Blender .blend file I used to make the rendering using the new Cycles rendering engine in case you would like to do your own renderings or learn more about Blender. Highly recommended.

1) Print
2) Play
3) Win!
4) ??
5) Profit! This thing requires a printer with a larger build platform than currently found at MakerBot (I really hope they make bigger printers soon!). But feel free to adjust for your printer. You could probably pack the pieces a little tighter together.

comments.text: Great setup! Renosis creations combined with practical solutions makes it a winner anyday.
comments.author: Bluemetal

comments.text: yep that's exactly it. i had to do it because my heat bed came warped, so i first gorilla glued it down to an MDF sheet to get it perfectly flat thinking that would work perfectly. The problem is that, it turns out (hindsight 20/20), the heat bed and the MDF warp differently during heating, so during an 8 hour print the parts would pop off the glass after about 6 hours. not fun. So i realized if there was a sealed air pocket then the heat would still make it through the glass and a warping build platform would not be able to bend the glass because of the air pocket. so now i can do 8 hour prints again. yay.
comments.author: Bluemetal

comments.text: That would solve my warped heat bed issue too.

title: DuMMY Model of Arduino Nano (may be a clone)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Arduino Nano Clone Dummy Model MEASURED FROM MY CLONE BOARD: APPROXIMATELY RIGHT - Not drawn from the internet "Mech Drawing" - http://www.slideshare.net/clickengenharia/arduino-nanomanual23 - I don't think that's the official Arduino mech sizes, but it's not the same as I measured. So please beware. Check your Arduino Nano dimensions against this and the drawing to see which matches better. Though the drawing doesn't give standard dot pitches of the solder points - which most will have - so I guess the drawing is wrong - but make your own mind up! Dummy for sizing up and building a case. When I say "Building a Case" I don't mean like a class action against Just3DPrint in Philidelphia. I mean a printable case for my daughter's science project. It involves a Arduino Nano and a LCD Screen Sheild from a Nokia. I bought a cheap one, and it gets a little funny with the contrast sometimes, I've no idea if its the Cheap Arduino Nano Clone or the cheap Nokia LCD Style Shield. It may just be a duff USB Power Supply - but either way something is messed up a little. DON'T PRINT. NOT AVAILABLE FOR JUSTPRINT3D TO PUT ON eBAY. Please note:
Stepan Malkovych
Will Davey
Matthew Andraka
Ryan Simms

Peace out EUR ING Andy Southern
aka BathRobotics p.s. A lot of Arduinos out there are Clones, I believe they are tolerated by the developers. Many of these have cheaper chipsets and Power regulators (where applicable) - you do get what you pay for.
However, in light of the whole @JPI Just3D Print (Philadelphia) thing, I'd urge any Arduino users out there to DONATE to the Arduino cause:
https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Donate
For the cost of a coffee you can avoid being the next Will Davey / Matthew Andraka et al over at Wharton's Spin out Just3D Print. Help Arduino developers "make end meat". (based on discussion held at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1350837/#comments )

description.text:
Minecraft Fans I made the Spider Queen BOSS
Teacher Ryan Made by piggylol

This is my prototype of an abstract game for two player!
There are both the files to print all the components with a 3D printer (with two kind of board) and there are also the files to make your paper version of the game.
As you can imagine my English is not very good, so if you see some mistakes in the rules, please give me a feedback! THANKS! PS
After print files, the board and the pieces has to be painted: please refers to rules (that has been written to use tokens and stickers) to determine the colors of the pieces.

Paint components Board has to be painted black and white (like chess board). You have to paint also border areas. If you see at the "PeP_board_pieces" you should understand what color to use. Also for the other game pieces, refer to the "PeP_board_pieces".
Instead of ptint cards, you can use the STL of "tessere board" and color them like in "cards_poker.pdf".

The large version is just under 3cm wide.  The small one is scaled by 75%.
This ornament obeys the three laws of robotics.
Skeinforge --> Print --> Hang

remixed_from.author: Weldingrod1
remixed_from.title: Triple LM6UU bearing extruder mount for Emaker Huxley

title: Huxley E3D Lite6 Mount (with GT2 Belt clamp X-carriage) v0.9

description.text:
I needed a clamp for my new E3D Lite 6 hotend. The original hotend on my second-hand Huxley was pretty hopeless and the X-carriage fell apart/warped. My initial design has lost about 5mm Z-Axis travel (ie the nozzle is 5mm lower than the stock setup) and moved the head about 7mm further from the X-Axis rods which hasn't really impacted the usable print area on the compact Huxley too much. I've added a heat shield to prevent x carriage warp. This is made from a scrap of coke can cut with scissors to size. The hole centres on the the X carriage are as standard though I've opened the holes up to accept M3 bolts. I've use washers with nuts as theses speak the load better than an nut trap and are easier to print! The X-Cariage is remixed from Weldingrod's design to allow the use of a GT2 belt on my Huxley as I've upgraded to CNC'd 16 tooth pulleys. Requires
2of M3 x 40 socket cap bolt
2of M3 x 20 button head bolt
4of M3 nut
4of M3 washer
2of miniature screws (to hold heat sink)
1 scrap of polished coke can to act as heat shield NOTE this is a work in progress and will update once I've tested it more! TESTING NOTES SO FAR......... The fan shroud is set a tan angle so that the fan just clears the X axis motor end when the X carriage is at the limit of it's travel. This still allows excellent airflow through the heat sink. If you get the angle wrong the fan collides with the X Axis motor end before it hits the limit switch when trying to home. I'm planning to beef up the mount a little to take a bit more flex out on the mounting L plate and add a stop to allow the fan shroud to be aligned so it can't hit the X axis motor mount. I'm trying to keep the moving mass of the X Carriage down as much as possible as I'm planning to add a part cooling fan soon(ish). Will upload when done. (ps In case you wondered my printer has been christened Bertha and I'll upload the STL's with out the name on in future!)

remixed_from.author: RxBConcept
remixed_from.title: MPCNC - Original corner block with limit switches

title: MPCNC - Original corner block with limit switches Remix for US & IE Version

description.text:
Update Rev9
I had some interference fit problems with the original, so I changed a few things to fix that & also made a version to use Mechanical switches instead of the circuit boards. The y-axis mechanical version may be a tight fit getting the wire on there, but looks like it should work. I have also uploaded a U.S. & IE version of each design. There is an openscad file for the 2 designs that you can also change to your liking. One downside to this design is you can only print it in the upright position. I copied the geometry of this design into openscad, so it should work for US or IE version. You just need to change the variable:
EMT_OD = 23.6; //For US version
EMT_OD = 25; //For IE version For the U.S Version that uses the circuit board switch use the STL files:
Corner_Block_LockRemix_WithLimitSwitchBoard_A_Rev9_repaired.stl (For Minimum limit switch)
Corner_Block_LockRemix_WithLimitSwitchBoard_B_Rev9_repaired.stl (For Maximum limit switch) For the U.S Version that uses the mechanical switch use the STL files:
Corner_Block_LockRemix_WithMechLimitSwitch_A_Rev9_repaired.stl (For Minimum limit switch)
Corner_Block_LockRemix_WithMechLimitSwitch_B_Rev9_repaired.stl (For Maximum limit switch) The International versions have a prefix of IE_ for the STL files. For reference, I used the Limit Switch: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1039934 I included STL files for the 2 opposite corners like the original version. You can also create your own modified version from editing the included openscad file. There are 2 STL files that just used for reference in the openscad file, the limit switch circuit board the CornerBlock. I am using 4 M2x10mm with a locknut to connect the Limit switch boards. M2.5 would work better, but I did not have those in a 10mm length. I used M2.5x16mm bolts for the mechanical switches, but 14mm length will probably also work. After installing this, I realized this idea will only work for the Min. X & Y switches. The center section is too far away when it hits the limit at the maximum.

description.text:
Customizable L or T outside corner bracket for aluminum extrusion. Permits customization of number of holes on each leg, size of extrusion, size of (or presence of) guide bars, and size of holes. Easy printing in the default orientation with no steep overhangs or bridges. Changelog:

1.0: Initial Version

Notes: I've been printing these with a 0.5mm nozzle, 0.2mm layers, and 20% infill to crank them out quickly. They won't take a great deal of lateral stress this way (you may want them on both sides of your extrusion if you're expecting loads this way), but quite strong on their plane. Have not yet tried lateral loads with 100% infill.

A friend with an Apprentice needed a bulked up motor mount to replace the much more fragile stock part. This is an exact fit compared to the OEM part (same hole paterns and spacing, same motor standoff length and angle, etc.), but with thicker bracing and a few of the superfluous holes deleted.  
I printed in ABS on an MBI 2X @ 100% fill with 3 shells & .20mm height using MakerWare / Skeinforge. It's considerably more rigid, not too heavy and everything bolted right up.

description.text:
This filter wheel can be used for 9x1.25 inch filters or 5x2 inch filters. It has Female T2 thread on both sides. This is an improved version of the 9-position filter wheel (thing 1329038). It's equiped with spring-loaded ball bearing click stops which provides a better and more stable positioning of the filters. A stainless steel spring (7.5 mm diameter and a length of approx. 20-25mm is used.
It's also a bit bigger (174x174 mm) but can house a 9x1.25 inch or 5x2 inch filter wheel.
There are a few accessories included (1.25 and 2 inch nose piece, brace and T2 male-to-male adapter).

comments.text: Excellent design PJ!  Printed well on my Maker Select Plus at .1mm 40mm/s .4mm hotend.  However, discovered that my camera filters are 48mm filters, not quite 2in/50mm, so they don't screw in.  Took a look at the source code you also posted, but its for the 1.25" filters.  Looking to mod the 2" plate to fit my filters.  I suspect it could be done from what you've shared, but I have only done one simple CAD modification in TinkerCAD.  Can't figure out how to mod the 1.25" filter wheel to fit five 48mm filters.  I'm thinking about just scaling the whole thing by a couple percent to achieve a fit.  Thanks for sharing a very useful thing!
comments.author: USNSCPO

comments.text:
Thanks for your compliments!
As far as I know, 2 inch filters have M48x0.6 threads. Those are the threads I've used. It's possible that the threads of that file are to wide. I've actually designed them a bit bigger to account for the bad tolerances of my old 3d printer.
I've just included a source file (sourcefile_2inch_fw.stp) that you can open in FreeCad or 123D Design (http://autodesk-123d-design.en.lo4d.com/).
That way you can resize them. Please do not scale the pitch of the thread.
comments.author: USNSCPO

comments.text: I should have checked my filters before assuming they were small.  They are indeed M48x0.6.  I thought they may be slightly different because they are 30 year old photography filters made by Tiffen.  I strongly suspect I have a mechanical issue with accurate print scale?   In my FW print, the holes measure 48.38 to 48.72, while the filters measure 47.75.  I better recheck my axis alignments and run a calibration print.  I appreciate the source file, and will try to use it once I'm sure I'm printing accurately.  Thanks for reminding scaling won't work.  Didn't think about it.  I don't want the threads to change, just the circumference of the hole they live in.  duh!
comments.author: PJHGerlach

comments.text:
The threadholes ARE bigger then the actually required ones. Just because my old printer had lousy tolerances. Please use the Step-file and scale down the individual thread disks (only in the x-y direction) until it suits your printer resulting in good threads.
Even better, use one of the thread disks and cut out a test slice to see what scaling factor is the best.

description.text:
UPDATE 2: If you cut a piece of 26.5cm copper tape and ONLY REMOVE THE PAPER BACKING AT THE VERY ENDS to create two sticky pads, then bridge the dipole feed (where the wires are soldered) your antenna will work better. This is called a hairpin match. See the return loss plot that shows with and without (return loss is the amount of signal bounced back at you, which means it didn't go where you wanted it to. Lower is better). If you remove the paper backing, it won't work correctly at that length anymore. 
UPDATE: Please trim 3.5cm from EACH END of the driven element and 2cm from END END of the reflector. Do not trim the director. This will bring the antenna into tune at 145.5Mhz. Do not trim if you only wish to use this antenna with 137Mhz weather satellites. 
A designed a short 2m 3 element yagi antenna that can be laser cut from 1/8" plywood or MDF for use with kiddos of all ages. The elements are all labeled and only require some glue and copper tape to complete the conductive portions. 
This is not the best antenna ever, but it works very well due to its light weight, small size, and fast assembly time. 
This is designed to have an RTLSDR with stock antenna chopped off and the coax directly soldered to the drive element (which must have a small gap in the center).
See photos of finished antenna for more details.

author: Mystic_Monster7

title: Airtight Filament Box Part
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I saw some ideas on how to make an airtight filament box but wanted to create my own version. I use a Robox which has it's own smartreel filament but I use the printer so much every day for work and over a variety of colours (lots of open filament rolls!) and I don't like the fact the filament is left in the open air whilst printing so I tend to avoid buying filament on smartreel and go for the same kind but on generic filament spools. 
For the box itself I wanted an easy, strong and quick way of adding and storing the filament. I used 25mm conduit tube and cut 25mm holes to slide it into the box and out the other side. It is still airtight this way and I find it to be stronger than adding supports for the pipe inside due to plastic boxes having a bit of give. If you don't cut a good circle and therefore leave a little air gap you can add a hair bobble or a couple elastic bands flush where the pipe meets the box and that covers any hole while still allowing easy removal of the pipe. One tip for the pipe. You want the hole as tight as possible but this makes inserting the pipe difficult. What to do is cut the pipe end at an angle and that makes it so much easier to insert into the hole. Also, I put all the silicone sachets I can find in the bottom of the box as an added measure. You can buy hundreds of them on amazon or ebay for a couple of pound/dollars. For people in the UK or Ireland, I got my boxes from Tesco. They're fantastically strong, look as good as a plastic box can look, fit filament perfectly (4 rolls) have a good closure and only cost £4.
The part I've uploaded is for the filament to come out of. You can print one for each filament roll and block it with something when not in use, but what I have done is print two for each filament. One goes at the bottom where the filament comes out and then the other one higher up is for the filament to go back in (making it airtight). I used 4mm (2mm inside) teflon tube which fits inside the hole nice and snugly. When using that filament just take out the teflon tube from the top piece and slot it into the printer (or take the teflon tube off if that's easier) and then when it isn't in use, insert it into the part on the top and that keeps it airtight. You don't necessarily have to add a hole into the box to the top one. I'd suggest not because when you're using that filament roll, the teflon tube isn't covering the hole. I've left the white filament without the parts to highlight the before and after.
I'm not great at describing what I mean (that's not what I'm here for!) so the pictures should explain it all.
The screws I used are about 3.5mm width and I designed the part to allow the top of the screw to be countersunk. The top of my screws were 9mm which is fairly big so you shouldn't have problems fitting most.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20-30

Notes: Very easy and quick print (depending on settings and printer, about 25min). I print each colour in place of a good purge between filament colour changes and that way I'm using filament that would otherwise go to waste. You will require 2 screws for each part you print. I doubt anyone would want to steal this to sell, but with all that is going on in the 3d printing world right now it goes without saying - you can print this to your hearts desire but don't sell it or profit from it. Let's not ruin the 3d printing community with selfish acts. Support Sad Face! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1350837

description.text:
This customizable spool generator is circumference centric so it's easy to calculate the amount of thread or wire on the spool. One turn can be calculated using the pythagorean theorem using the pitch and circumference as your length and height.
This way, using a stepper motor it will be easy to regulate the amount of thread or wire spent.

author: chev383

description.text:
The Orca 0.3 from mendel-parts.com has a very tricky z-endstop. It's totally non-adjustable and is connected with one single tiewrap to one pole. So it totally needed a redesign to make the z-axis adjustable.
The X-axis suffers from the same problems, and I will also redesign that one within some weeks from now. I'm also designing an extruder light for the dark winter days. So follow my account if you have an Orca 0.3 and want to improve it!

• Print the parts. Best is to use the combined one. I've printed mine with a 0.22 layer on 35mm/s. You could print a bit slower then me to improve quality.
  • During printing start by connecting the wires to the lever switch as illustrated in the pictures.
  • Wait for the print to finish and drink some coffee (tea not allowed!). I took a shower however, which isn't easy to combine with drinking coffee...
  • When the print is finished carefully put the switch inside the holder. This can be hard when you chose inflexible wires. Just take your time.
  • Put both nuts inside the base part, now use a bolt to pull the nuts inside. Remove the bolt afterwards.
  • Put the bolts through the holder, add the spring, and attach the bolts to the nuts in the base part as illustrated. Do not tighten too much.
  • Now attach the base-part to the Y-bed as illustrated
  • Connect the wires to a connector. When you are using Gen6 electronics then then connect the wires to the outermost 2 pins of the OPTO-Z-Connector (pin 4 and 5).
  • You will need new firmware for the optos to work. I've written a patch for the marlin firmware which can be downloaded here: http://code.google.com/p/mendel-bed-mapper/downloads/detail?name=Marlin%2Blevelbed.zip&can=2&q=
  • Calibrate your z-axis and start enjoying this wonderful piece of technology...

description.text: A math model of conic sections - a cone cut into sections to show hyperbola, ellipse and parabola.
My math Algebra II teacher taught us about conic sections last year and I thought it would be useful to have a 3D printed physical model of the different sections of a cone.

Objectives: This model illustrates the concept of conic sections. Students can view and interact with the physical model to help them understand things like hyperbolas, parabolas and ellipses. Audiences: High algebra and precalculus school students Preparation: Students will need to know a fair level of algebra and some introduction to conic sections in order to understand what the model represents Steps:
  • Idea - My math Algebra II teacher taught us about conic sections last year and I thought it would be useful to have a 3D printed physical model of the different sections of a cone.
  • Design - I used Blender to build the model

title: Star Wars inspired Maz Kanata Glasses

description.text:
In latest Star Wars film, The Force Awakens, there is an alien character that wears unusual glasses with a support structure each side of the head for each lens and no nose bridge (see photo of my laptop).
To make your own, print these parts, use a raft for printing, trim off the support structures.
Glue each structure to each side of your non-favourite headphones. There is a hinge each side allowing the glass for each eye to be opened out or closed over the eye. The bulging lenses are 4cm diameter clear plastic baubles sold on line. They come apart into two halves so you can fill them with whatever you like. I trimmed down each half and used them to make the "lenses".
Designed in Google Sketchup. skp and stl files attached.

Das soda-CanStein!  This object is inspired by thinkgeeks'a can-in-stein April Fools joke.  Ever since I saw that, I wanted to have one of my own.  One that was a real object, not a joke. 
This soda can holder uses a screw-in plug on the bottom to hold the can in place.  It only makes contact on a very narrow band on the top and bottom, so it will keep the beverage cooler than if it was in your full-contact heat-transferring hands.  The lid pivots away to allow beverage consumption, as is right and proper.
The CanStein was designed to print entirely without supports.  The inter-piece gaps are generous, to allow easy assembly.  Use appropriate viscosity glue or epoxy for final assembly.  The entire object was designed from scratch in Autodesk Fusion 360.  -Love this program!

Printer:

Wilson II

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron, 100 micron for pivot

Infill:

15% hexagonal, 100% for pivot

Notes: I used FoxSmarts' translucent gold filament (available for cheap on Amazon. It's Prime, too!). It gave a nice brassy look. Print two of the pivot halves. All else is "print one". Using these settings in Slic3r used 281 grams of PLA in my printer. (WOOT! I'm gonna print two more right now!)

The lid and the lid ring are to be glued together.  The body and the left/right handle sections also become one unit.  Assemble the handle first, then attach to the body.  The lid assembly pivot has two halves (print two), and is retained using a bit of 1.75 filament through the retainer/pivot end.  Use the standard "melt-the-end" technique to turn the filament length into a rivet.  The pivot halves can be glued together.

I spent a couple of years of thinking about "how would I make a soda can holder that also insulates nicely?" (and looks like a fliptop mug),then implemented it those thoughts using Autodesk Fusion 360.  
I dislike supports intensely.  Not because I can't print them (I can), but because they are wasteful of my precious filament.   As much as possible, my designs are support-free.  Glue is easy to get cheaply.  Filament is either easy to get, or cheap.  Not both.  Down with support!  Up with printing-a-bunch-of interlocking-pieces and then-gluing-them-together...

Please, feel free to remix this!  My sculpting ability is teh suck.  It really needs to be more ornate.  Sculpting ornate vines and oak leaves and forest scenes would be realllllly cool.  Have at it.  Be creative.  Give proper attribution.  And DON"T sell this design, or designs based on this object.  If you want to sell designs, make your own from scratch.  ;)

comments.text:
So I just printed all the parts...went to assemble and the handles do not even come close to fitting in their designated slot. Crud..
When the two handle halves are placed together they are too wide at the top to fit in the slot. Same at the bottom. I shaved off at least 1/16" of the sides of the bottom, but still no go. Same for the top. And even if the width where shaved down, I don't think it would fit anyhow as the geometry won't allow it. And the bottom is actually at least 1/8" short of hitting the bottom of the cutout/recess....Otherwise it looks great
comments.author: superpotatofudge

comments.text: Not sure what the issue would be.  I didn't do any trimming on the one in the picture.  Is it possible that your z axis is printing larger than x/y?   Since the handle halves are oriented in a different plane for printing, that might be a possibility.
comments.author: superpotatofudge

comments.text: Well I would say that's entirely possible...but the screw plug for the bottom fits just fine..hmm And the lid ring fits the cap and the pivot pin fits its respective holes..etc. The only thing that seems off dimensional is the handle mount grooves. I did print with a brim so originally thought I hadn't shaved it all off. Will investigate further in a bit.
comments.author: bainite

comments.text:
Well I printed a 20mm cube. As measured by my calipers... Y 19.87 X 20.05 Z 20.36
So the Y stepping must be off a hair, but I can't see that causing the gap I'm experiencing for the height of the handles. It would explain the TINY fraction of a lip I see at feel at the top of the body after pressing the handle down into its recess. Depending on how tight the tolerances you built into the model are, the Z being a bit over-sized could explain why the bottom groove won't accept the handle. I'm planning to do a bit of sanding on it tonight.
comments.author: superpotatofudge

comments.text: I measured the gap, it's 0.25mm.  I created a copy of the handle halves, and moved the body-mating surfaces back 0.50mm.  That brings it to a 0.75mm gap.  The new handle parts are uploaded with "-loose" appended.  I've included images of the interface at the top.  I also moved the mating surface at the bottom.  Only the handle sections were edited.
comments.author: superpotatofudge

comments.text: Cool, thanks! It's printing now.
comments.author: bainite

comments.text: Worked out very well, if not a bit loose. Glued in and working good. The only problem I'm having is the lid not laying completely flat on top the body, but that seems likely due to the very slight short on the Y axis as previously seen. I need to recalibrate to get my steps up to match the X and Z dimension. No biggie though, the stein works pretty good as it is. Thanks!

description.text: Ratner key change safe locks, 3d printable version. There are some small changes with this lock and the original to make it 3d printable. This lock was installed in Ratner safes, made in England and exported around the world. Have seen only one of these in Brisbane before. The lock is quite unique in that the key can be easily changed. Once the safe lock is unlocked, inserting a new key sets a new combination. The combination is set every time the safe is unlocked, as the levers and the combination wheels are independent. http://24hourlocksmith.com.au/3d-printed-safe/ It has only 6 different parts that are easy to print. There are 7 wheels and 7 levers. The key is thicker then the original safe key to make it stronger. When printing, i use a piece of cardboard to support the underside of the flag. Use hairspray if the plastic will not stick to the cardboard.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4

Infill:

all solid except for bolt and body. they are at 40%
Designed on the Ratner safe lock from Ratner safe company in England. manufactured over 100 years ago. http://www.brisbanecitylocksmiths.com.au/repair-safe-in-brisbane/ratner-safes/

title: Folger Tech MK9 Jhead Mount & Fan Shroud

description.text:
I have finished the part, and included a meshmixered version with supports that worked quite well for my printer. The entire thing works fairly well, I just need some correct length screws to get it down nice and snug. You'll need m3x20mm screws for the groovemount, as well as for hinge, and m3x25mm screws to mount it to the stepper. This part goes under a Folger Tech MK9 (Or possible MK7) extruder, and allows you to attach a groovemounted hot end. It's a nice step up from the regular hot end, and doesn't require you to buy a new bowden setup, or print yourself a new extruder yet. I would suggest, however, either upgrading the stepper on the MK9, or printing yourself a new extruder. From my experience with the MK9 (with the default stepper), is that it doesn't extrude smoothly, and leaves marks on the outside of the print. I have changed the hole sizes to fit screws a bit better, as well as added a hinge-mount for a fan shroud, which is also included. 3/15/2016: I have now included an ABL probe which could directly replace the cooling fan on the jhead.
Happy printing!

Printer:

Voxel Ox

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Print with the filament feed hole horizontal for best results. A version with support is also provided.

You'll most likely need to drill the holes for your fan shroud a little bit.  I used a 1/8 inch drill bit, and just opened the opening of the hole up a bit.  It threads quite well.  I also drilled out the holes for the hinge, and just put an M3 screw through it.  Since it rests on the fan, it doesn't really need a nut, but if you want to add one it couldn't hurt anything.

The Pill Pill is the last capsule you'll ever need to hold your pills, coins, gummy bears, glasses, teeth, band-aids, trinkets, tactical chocolates, emergency hot sauce rations, or any other assorted bric-a-brac. Printed at 75% scale, it is about the size of a regular pill bottle. Print it at 100% for larger items like a candy bar or a hidden set of keys, or scale it down even further for smaller knick-knacks like beads, buttons, jewelry, and small pebbles and baubles.
  • Featuring an advanced 3 way locking mechanism, it seals tightly and securely every time.
  • For optimal performance, an o-ring can be added for a firm waterproof seal.
  • If you scale it down to 75% from any size, it will nest neatly inside its self.
  • Works wonderfully at any size!
    • The walls are thick, making the structure extremely strong and resilient to dropping. The ends are weighted so the halves will stand upright without falling over.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

yes

Notes: Print two of each half in each color and mix and match them. Use rafts and supports if you want the ends to come out nice and smooth.

MaverickMario's design was intended to be printed huge, for a life size Dr Mario prop. When scaled down its walls became too thin and it didn't work right for me.  I started out by modifying it to print at the smaller scale that I wanted, to use it as an actual container. I thickened the walls and made the ends heavier so they would stand up. Then I modified it so that the two halves meet up flush with each other in the center.  Over several iterations, I ended up engineering a whole new locking mechanism and beefing up the entire design.

author: HawkriderPrints

title: Continuous rotary to intermittent rotary via a Reuleaux triangle

description.text:
This is basically a re-design for 3D printing of the mechanism posted on GrabCad here: https://grabcad.com/library/reuleaux-triangle-intermittent-mechanism-1
Based on a (modified) Reuleaux triangle (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuleaux_triangle#Rotation_within_a_square) the mechanism converts continues rotary motion to intermittent rotary motion. The Reuleaux triangle providing movement to and from the gear-to-be-rotated and the rotation of that gear. Very neat, I reckon.
Designed in Moment of Inspiration (Moi), simulated in SimLab Composer Mechanical and printed in Diamond Age PLA on an Ultimaker original.
Note that included in the stl files is an optional part Reuleaux rotor spacer. You may not need to use this if you can print everything flat enough. I found that I could fully tighten all 'keeper' screws, but not the screws retaining the handle lever. In the photos and video I've spaced the handle lever out with stainless steels washers, but they are fiddly to fit so I subsequently designed the aforementioned spacer.
Note also that the posted stl files differ slightly from the model that I printed. I've changed the hub keeper set up from 3 screws to one screw, and added 3 more holes in the base to accommodate a wider range of rubber bands.
Hardware required:
1 longish rubber band
3mm x 10mm long button head cap screws. At least 11 with a maximum of 16.
A video of the model 'in action' is here: https://youtu.be/_lvGsT3ATXw
A simulation is here: https://youtu.be/HkxusRPVYAA
A 3D pdf file in which you can rotate the model to any attitude and then run it is included in the files.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

generally 0.2mm see Misc. Notes

Infill:

30%

Notes: Material: I used Diamond Age PLA.
If you need the Reuleaux rotor spacer, which is only 0.5mm thick as designed, 0.1mm resolution is appropriate otherwise 0.2mm is, I think, fine.
Generally for models of mechanisms, such as this, I use 1.2mm wall section everywhere.
For the larger parts I strongly recommend a good sized brim to minimise warping.
NOTE. I have NOT oriented the parts for printing. Some will have a suitable orientation, but most do NOT.

Firstly the normal cleaning up.
I use a tapered reamer to clear excess from all holes.
For holes in which parts rotate I bring the holes to size with the appropriately sized hand reamer.
Note that the hole in the handle lever that accepts the handle stem should NOT be reamed out. The handle stem should be a tap fit into the handle lever.
All parts should rotate freely.
Finally, the rubber band. You should aim to have the rubber band hardly stretched at all when the pawl is engaged in the gear. Use as long a rubber band as possible and screw a 3mm x 10mm (or a bit longer) screw into the appropriate hole.

This part is to upgrade the folger tech 2020 prusa i3 kit to have a v-slot Y axis.  Its basically two corner brackets, only it accounts for going over the stepper in the back.  My printer was pretty horrible with the bearings that came with it, and would actually do a skipping motion instead of sliding smoothly, so I decided to upgrade to the far superior v-slot.

Parts Needed Various M4 screws, and tnuts to match
3 v-wheel kits from openbuilds.org part store, or similar
3 M5x25 screws for the vwheels
1 eccentric spacer from openbuilds.org
2 1/4" spacer
1000mm of v-slot from openbuilds.org part store
Hack saw, miter saw, band saw, or something to cut v-slot with Step 1 On the side that has a single bearing, drill out the outer of the bearing-holder holes to 11/16th. This will be your eccentric spacer hole. Step 2 On the side with two bearing holders, drill out the two outer holes to 1/4th inch. These will be the holes for your non-eccentric mounted wheels. Step 3 Cut your v-slot with either a hack saw, or a miter saw. Precision doesn't really matter, as long as they're long enough to allow the spacers to screw into them. Shoot for somewhere around 16" long to span the length of the printer. Step 4 Put your wheels on, using your 1/4" spacers on the side with two wheels, and your eccentric on the side with only one. Make sure the eccentric spacer is as wide as it can be. Don't forget to add the shims! And don't over-tighten your nuts!
Order for parts:
screw -> spacer -> shim -> bearing -> wheel -> bearing -> shim -> nut Step 5 Put drop in t-nuts on the bottom of your spacers, as well as in the sides. Slide your pieces of v-slot into them, and place them on the frame of your printer. Put the bed out side of them, and push them outwards so that the wheels are a little loose, but not falling down. Step 6 To make sure that your axis goes straight back and not at an angle, use a caliper or tape measure to make sure that both the front and back ends of one of your vslot extrusions are an equal distance away from the outside frame of your printer. The goal is to get it parallel, so you know that your extrusion is heading straight back. Then, Tighten this one down if its near where you want it. With the second piece, push it out into the wheel on the other side so that its relatively tight. Then, measure between the first vslot piece and the second one and adjust it until it is an equal distance away in the front and the back. Tighten this one down, making sure the bed's wheels are resting inside of the v slot. Step 7 Adjust the eccentric spacer until your Y axis gantry no longer wobbles. Step 8 Enjoy having silky smooth, and quiet linear motion on your new, fancy Y axis!

comments.author: dannycarter85

comments.text: I wouldn't have time to do that but I can tell you how I did this one. Take a picture of your model plan with the cowl, or download the plans from online. Then open a 3D model in you CAD software of choice, I used Fusion 360. Import your picture and scale it to size. Now add a T-Spline or in other words a freeform base feature and apply symmetry (left to right of cowl) and start moving nodes and faces to fit your picture better and better. On the top of the model cowl (open part) you can do the same thing and have it fit, I didn't need a picture for this one since it was almost circular I could constrain it to a certain width or height. Once your shape matches from both views, you can add features separate from the curves, such as vents or the prop hole. Now either shell it out and export, or export as a solid body and print with no infill and no top (if you can print the cowl as a single perimeter layer, which is best for low weight). Hope this helps, good luck!

remixed_from.author: h3ss
remixed_from.title: E3D Hot End Mount for Rostock

title: E3D versions 5 & 6 Bowden (groovemount) Hot End Mounting Plates for Rostock MAX & Orion

description.text:
This is for the E3D all-metal hot end from http://e3d-online.com, specifically the Bowden version. (Totally worth the extra money!) I have also designed part cooling fan ducts specifically to work with this mount, when the hot end is mounted under the effector (not above): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:487768 6/7/15: Version 6 upper and lower now have marginally tighter tolerances. I found that the previous version worked better with some filaments than others, presumably because some experience more die swell (thermal expansion after it comes out of the nozzle) than others. The new version will offer a tighter fit. If you print it and it's too tight, try reducing filament flow. For parts like this that require tight tolerances, it's a good idea to measure your filament with a digital micrometer in 10 different places. Put the average into your slicer as the filament diameter. 10/6/14: Version 6 upper and lower mounting plates have been changed to match the E3D v6's mounting profile. If you're using an older version, print this and throw the old one away! The old version works alright, but is less resistant to letting the hot end get knocked around by running into printed plastic that isn't laying flat. This can cause layer shifting! The new plates have been altered (lower is taller, upper is shorter) to fit perfectly.
.
Your hot end mount is critical in maintaining high print quality! If you use this, it's a good idea to use the Watch feature so you can get updates when new versions are released.
.
NOTE: This comes with top-mount spacers that you can print for mounting your E3D on top of the effector platform. I get jams when I do this. If you can't get your hot end to print PLA without jamming, mount the hot end UNDER the effector. I suspect it has something to do with the effector absorbing heat from the hot end and radiating it back. When it's mounted underneath, the problem goes away.
.
Older changelogs are in the Instructions tab.
.
I got the general idea of how to do a groovemount from http://tricklaser.com/ and the two-plate idea from h3ss. The model was done from scratch in Sketchup.
.
NOTE: Make sure you have your fan turned on all the time. Hot wire it if you can. If you have the extruder heat turned on but the fan is turned off, the mounting plates may warp.

The lower plate (the one with the gaping hole in the side) slides sideways onto the narrow part of the hot end near the top. The upper plate slides down over the top of the hot end and should contact the lower plate.
.
The best fasteners for this are some #6-32 screws, two of which should be 1.5" or longer, and one of which should be 3" or longer, and some #6-32 nylon lock-nuts. Nearest metric equivalents are fine. Put some heat shrink tubing around the long screw (but don't actually shrink it with hot air) and then zip-tie the hot end wiring to the screw, using the heat shrink to protect the wires from the screw threads.
.
There is 0.15mm of clearance around the dimensions of the E3D. Both pieces should seat firmly around the hot end and not allow any slop at all. If it's too loose, increase your filament multiplier. If it won't go on at all (or without bending something) reduce your filament multiplier. Remember that this hot end is somewhat fragile, especially around the heat break, so be careful during installation.
.
Old changelogs:
9/17/14: Version 6 top mount spacer added.
.
10/31/13: Made the cable management tang a little longer, braced up the clip with the tang, rotated the geometry in the .stl files to be print-ready, and added an "All-In-One" .stl so that you can print everything in one pass. I recommend 30mm/sec or a part cooling fan to make sure the top-mount spacer comes out nice.
.
10/6/13: Even better cable management, taller top-mount spacer: The upper mounting plate w/ cable management has been improved to provide built-in strain relief. Instead of one side clip, there are now two, and one of them has a tang in the middle. The idea is that you feed the cables up through the one with the tang, then back down around the tang, then around to the other clip and finally up again. Should be clear in the photo. (I got the idea from how the Budaschnozzle does strain relief.) The spacer is also a couple of millimeters taller to improve airflow over the bottom cooling fin. I recommend 3" or longer #6-32 screws.
.
9/2/13: Added printable spacer. The 1.5" spacers I recommended previously aren't tall enough to expose the bottom heat sink fin to the airflow from the fan duct. If you've had any PLA jams on long prints, this should fix it. If you prefer metal spacers, get something 41-45mm long. Your existing screws will work (just barely) but I recommend 2.75" or more.
.
8/26/13: New version of top plate added with some sorely needed cable management!
.
8/23/13: Reduced the clearance from .25 to .15. Should print better without having to mess with the filament settings.

This is an all-weather housing for an All-Sky camera which can make use of any 1-1/4" body 'eyepiece' type camera from makers such as Altair or QHY etc. The lens f/l is optional, but the best for this job are probably 1.8 to 2.1mm focal length (offering 180-150deg FOV respectively). Note that this design needs an optical acrylic dome of some sort, the one used here is sold at modest price by Orion as a spare part for their own AllSky camera (;-)). It is worthwhile using a quality dome like this to get the best image quality possible, a cheap dome will cause distortions and probably reflections too. The seal can either be made from a dual-row of 3mm O-rings (I have made my own like this using cut lengths super-glued together). The seal part shown here can also be printed using TPE flexible fillament (shown above in white) and that seems to work well also. There are two electrical connections provided - the first is the necessary USB connection, and in this design I use a pair of wedge blocks (keyed) which when placed around the cable (USB A-B) it can be pushed into the rectangular opening in the side and will provide a reasonably weather-tight seal without further work. Using silicone sealant would be more effective but probably not necessary. Use a small cable tie on the insidepart of the cable to prevent it being pulled out. The round hole will accept a 2.5 x 5mm socket for connecting an external 12v supply to an internal heater. You can make your own here using nichrome wire or resistors - or even a commercial dew-band if you like, and the suggested power output would be around 5w (this is something of a guess!). The internal heater is needed to keep misting or dew forming on the outside of the dome, the heater is to be placed in the lower section (beneath the camera plate) and the warm air will rise through the holes and circulate around the inside of the dome. Where I am (UK) I've found the heater is essential on almost every night I've used the camera, if I forget to power the heater it will soon dew up! In addition to the heater I also keep some sachets of dessicant inside. I'll update this with material sources later... This was my source for the dome used here: http://www.scsastro.co.uk/catalogue/orion-allsky-camera-replacement-acrylic-dome-5857.htm?term=dome

Printer:

Wanhao 4S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes: Designed to be printed without supports, I use ABS for this job apart from the top weatherseal which is TPE. Care needs to be taken assembling the dome retaining ring to the main body, 12 screws are specified to provide even pressure all around but tightening must be done incrementally working your way around the ring several times. The ring is best printed with high infill (80% or so) for strength. Using either the printed TPE seal or a pair of 3mm O-rings the retaining seal should be compressed all the way down into contact with the main body of the casing. That will ensure the best chance of a 100% weather seal (it has been effective for me even in driving rain!). Addendum: You may need to chamfer slightly the inside/lower edge of the retaining ring. This is a close fit on the perspex dome and difficult to specify the exact shape needed. I have 4 of these domes and they vary a little with regards to the fillet at the bottom edge. I use a de-burring tool (designed for de-burring metal) to do this in a couple of seconds, you should really get yourself one of these anyway as it's a way quicker/easier/more-precise method of removing unwanted edges etc. This is the sort of thing I'm talking about: http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00NVPMV5I?keywords=de-burring%20tool&qid=1456888129&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1

title: Headphone Hanger - Universal - Fits Any Desk/Table/Shelf

description.text: The Universal Headphone Holder / Headphone Hanger fits securely to almost any desk, table, or shelf, up to 1-5/8 inches thick. Its interchangeable attachments come in two different sizes to fit most larger audiophile type headphones. It has been over engineered with enough strength to hold belts, hoses, purses, handbags, extension cords, and more. You will need to print two pieces, which securely lock together using a proprietary space age dovetail joint. The clamping mechanism prints fully assembled. It can be printed without support, if you want, but one side of the screw will be ugly. The tolerances are very tight, so its recommended to print at the finest layer height you can. This will ensure that it can clamp down tightly and hold fast. The more infill you use, the stronger it will be. When properly printed, this device is capable of holding large amounts of weight. I've provided both horizontal and vertical mounting equipment, as well as several customization options including Sony, AKG, MakerBot Jewelry Hand, and Darth Vader themes. The basic attachments can be printed with little to no infill and no support. Some, like the hand, may require some support to be printed. There is also a printable 1/2 in allen wrench included, which you can use to tighten it down I recommend personalizing the hanger with your own monogram, text, or logo before printing. You can print the two parts in the same color, or mix and match. The possibilities are endless!! 3/14/16 update - I've added another clamping mechanism (XL_headphone...) that is even bigger and stronger, for the most demanding applications. It includes built in support so that it can be printed supportlessly. You can see it in use, in the picture that says 'BAZ'

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes: Use lots of infill for strength on the clamp part. No supports or infill is needed on most of the attachments. I printed all of mine in PLA at 0.2mm layers. The Sony one in the picture is glow-in-the-dark PLA. The AKG one is pink because that's what I had laying around.

When the screw clamping mechanism comes off the printer, it will be frozen together.  Grab a couple pairs of channel locks and gently grip one on the screw head and one on the part it screws into.  Gently twist until you hear a snap, and the screw should now move freely.  Twist it all the way up and down a few times (using the optional allen wrench if you want) to clean out any loose debris.

I was inspired by anth92's design, but I wanted to make it stronger and adjustable. I tried out several different types of dovetail joints before I settled on this one, which can be printed without supports.  You can copy it to make your own custom attachments.

I needed a "dust cover" for a USB port that failed on a 5-port charger. I was always forgetting which port was bad... and then I'd wake up and some device hadn't charged all night. I put an X on the bottom/part facing out so that people think before they pull it out to plug their device in. NOTE: This prints pretty flush. Depending on your printer, it might be a tight fit. Don't plug it in a port that's recessed and that you want to use later on. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/41FGQygFDV2

Prints in just a couple minutes on almost any printer.

title: Triton TRA-001 with Incra Plate Lift Guide tube

description.text:
The Triton TRA-001 router with the Incra router table plate is a great combination for woodworking.  It is an economical solution because the router lift is built into the Triton router.  However, one issue I found is that when you took the height winder and put it through the hole in the router plate it was difficult to get it to engage with the router to adjust the router height because there isn't anything to guide it into place
This adapter mounts to the underside of the Incra router plate with double stick carpet tape.  It consists of the 3D printed part with a 2" piece of copper tubing (5/8" OD with 3/64" thick wall - available at a hardware store) that is simply epoxied to the 3D printed piece.  This design simplifies the 3D printing portion of the project because it eliminates printing an overhang.

comments.text: why the copper tube?  cant I just print the whole thing?
comments.author: chrismolloy

comments.text: For me it just simplified the design by eliminating the requirement of printing an overhang.  If that isn't an issue for you then you can certainly modify the design to add the tube to the stl and print it that way.
comments.author: chrismolloy

title: Gaax Pit Fighter (18mm Scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Gaax are superhumanly fast and can leap tremendous distances. These traits serve them well in the pits. What is less known is that they can touch your table at lunch and determine whether or not you had eggs and toast or milk and cereal for breakfast...okay they're not that good but they have a really enhanced sense of touch. Also, they get a bump to hearing. Basically, they're pretty cool all the way around! The Gaax were created using a random alien generator from our sci-fantasy RPG Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and are fully compatible with Wayfarer Tactics. If you'd like a 28mm or heroic scale version of the Gaax Pit Fighter scale up by 166.6%. Also, please check out our Patreon page. Thank you!

here is a lens adjusting wrench for a 12mm laser, so you can focus your laser while it is on and inside a housing. also just a 50mm spacer to set your z axis spacing from your work piece.

Coozie for my Diet Pepsi. Large base helps prevent knocking the can over.
The inside diameter of the coozie may vary depending on the cooling shrinkage of your material. The provided files worked fine using a fast profile with HIPS. .38 layer height, 1.92mm bottom thickness. I suggest you print only the top 10mm and test fit around your soda can before you print the whole thing. You can fine tune the inside diameter of the coozie by varying can_radius=67/2; 67 for the diameter worked good for HIPS Fast Profile using .38mm layer height and 1.92 bottom thickness. The thickness of the bottom directly under the can is 3mm.

title: Unit Cell of the Clathrate Hydrate type II

I made these parts to be able to mount the Official Raspberry PI 7 Inch touchscreen to a electronics box. I used a 6" x 8" box. These pieces are 5.375 inches long. They are designed to have the screen on the outside of the box and then you tighten the screws down and the plastic pulls the screen tight. I did not use foam between the screen and the box but there should be enough flex to be able to do that if you would like. I did make a lower part so there is clearance for the USB cable if you are powering your RPI with it. Check out my blog. I have just started but will be creating more things all the time.
Learn to build it

Two piece small clean enclosure for MSP430 Launchpad. Green and Red LED's on launchpad are visible with enclosure cover on and there are two holes in the top cover allowing the push buttons to be accessed. Female header pins on underside of launchpad are exposed in the lower part of the enclosure and fit flush to the bottom surface. Prints great with almost any settings and works great as a small and lightweight case to protect your MCU. Top cover is attached with 4x - M3x0.5mmx8mm socket cap bolts that thread into M3x0.5mmx3.8mm heat set inserts installed in lower part of enclosure. Part numbers have been included below. McMaster-Carr Part No's.
4x - M3x0.5mmx8mm socket cap bolts - 92290A113
4x - M3x0.5mmx3.8mm heat set inserts - 94180A331 Check us out at www.mattertec3d.com for all your 3d printing needs. You can also check out our similar enclosure design for an Arduino Leonardo here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1441657

As a Design teach its important that you follow the three "ing". Camping, Fishing and Partying. How to make Plastics
-print files as attached
-Plastic used is ABS and has been polish with acetone vapours
-A housing has been included for a 15x6x5mm bearing on both side.
Timber
-The timber was recycled from out floorboards in a scrap yard.
-The timber was laser cut (still looking for the files to upload). If you don't have a laser they can easily be cut with traditional tools.
-Timber finished with wattyl 7008 2 pack high gloss estipol (Super water resistant) but any estipol should be fine.
-Plastic and timber were joined with a 2 pack adhesive and hand sanded (don't forget to put the bearing in before you glue the timber cap over it).
Stainless steel
-I made a mould for the reel seat and pressed some scrap steel over it in a 6 Ton press.
-The arm is also scrap steel and was bent on a pan brake and spot welded to the real seat.
-I tapped the arm with a M6x1 Tap to allow me to double bolt the middle pin to allow the reel to spin freely.
Handle
-Are also glued into place with 2 pack adhesive which allows them to spin freely.

As well as 3D design and printing students will use a variety of skills.
-Stainless steel works
-Turning
-Thread cutting
-Spot Welding
-Metal forming
-Mixed media design
-Engraving
-Timber finishing

This project can be targets at a stage 5 level (15-16 years) and could be incorporated in Engineering, Metals and Design. With the variety of skills required this would need to be targeted at competent students. Adjustments can be made by pre producing components.
All the skills required have been developed over the previous 2-3 years of students schooling. As said previous, some components can be pre produced to reduce the complexity of the design.

Students should be able to design and produce their own version of this design. This may mean their design is larger or smaller, includes more engraving or inclusion of a side casting mechanism similar to an Alvey reel. Students can be marked on quality of finish and skills incorporated in to their design.

This stand can support any size tablet or phone. I've tested it with an Ipad1, Kindle Fire HDX 8.9, Kindle Fire HD 10, Kindle Fire HD 7 and various android phones. The 2 piece design makes it easy to fold up and pack away. It's tall enough to keep larger tablets well supported even in portrait position. .2mm resolution or better is recommended. The notches are a snug fit to position your tablet at a steep angle. I've included 2 files to use. One has the emblem cutout and the other is solid. These parts are interchangeable, so you can print out 2 blank pieces if you prefer a solid stand without any emblem. EDIT 12/8/2016 New models have been uploaded for better cable management. Grab "rebel_v3.stl" and "v5_base" for the latest set.

comments.author: andythefiredog

comments.text: LOL! Love the design but I wanted to make it have a Detroit Lions cut out... I am trying to learn mesh mixer so I did some fun manipulation to get a filled in version so I could then learn to cut out a shape... Just read your thing details to find you you already provided one! Some day I will learn to read the details ahead of time. Thanks for posting such an elegant design! Did you print it with wood? Looks really slick.
comments.author: theroar

comments.text: Yep, this one is in wood.  If you ever decide to play with wood filament I highly recommend Zen Toolworks wood filament and Hatchbox Wood PLA.  I also found that using a stiff paint brush to 'scrape' gel stain across the surface gives far better results than pictured here.
comments.author: theroar

comments.text: WOW! It is not what you know, but WHO you know! Tinkercad and that hole tool worked like a champ! Stand adjusted in less than 10 min... Need to run to school to get the blue and grey filament now. =) Sure do appreciate your tips! I will post a remake of the design and give you some props with my students when I record the new training as well. Thanks again!  Mike
comments.author: b1sh0p

comments.text: Very cool, no problem.  Just another tip, Hatchbox filaments are about $24 per 1kg spool on Amazon Prime.  Their specialty filaments (like wood) are about $35.  I would be interested in hearing more about your class, shoot me a message sometime.  Take care!
comments.author: theroar

comments.text: Thanks for the tip with the wood. I have not experimented at all with cool filaments like that. My budget for my classroom is so tight I have to juggle stuff just to get filament... I have found I am pretty good at grant writing, so I keep getting more hardware, but I need to find a way to fund the filament.

description.text:
Originally inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673497, but designed from scratch for my own needs. This tool holder clips onto one of the lower corner pieces of the BI 2.5 It holds:
  • 5 Hex Wrenches (5mm, 4mm, 3mm, 2.5mm, and 2mm)
  • Metal scraper
  • Tweezers
  • Needle nose pliers
  • Plastic scraper (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:596563)
  • Generic 20mm circular slot (currently used to hold mini bit driver http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:397940)

Printer:

BI 2.5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Prints upside down to avoid requiring supports.

I love all the pegboard parts out there, but I found all the bit holders to be too large to print, or way to complicated with long print times. I wanted something simpler, and while I am not very good at this, I managed to scratch this out using Twobraids' pegboard back.

Printer:

Afinibot i3 Prusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

30

Notes: I don't know if its Slic3r or me, but the supports it prints are terrible. I found that if I try to print the peg insert without support, the top pegs deforms slightly. I added in a hard "Support" that seemed to solve my problem, while also being very easy to remove. It may not actually be needed, but hey, works for me.

The (Deformed) Printed object I am still working on fine tuning my printer, its my first kit build! I printed two, I of course photographed the deformed one.
So, if you have a quick "This is clearly a case of " Please let me know!
